body:
Problem: When $VIMRUNTIME is inaccessible, there shows a confusing
E484 without explaining the root cause.

Solution: Validate $VIMRUNTIME by sourcing filetype.lua before
enabling filetype/syntax plugins. Show E5009 if it fails.

Fix #27527

comment_data.body: I think this is a bit of a weird place to "validate" VIMRUNTIME here as it is not really specific to lua. The problem could just as well manifest at the first time when wanting to load some .vim file. for the _startup_ part of #27527 , I'd rather add an explicit check as part of the startup sequence in `main()` (not sure where, maybe after initializing UI).

comment_data.body: let's avoid adding more things to `vim.` . we have `vim/_core/` , we can create new modules as needed or choose a more appropriate existing module in there. i guess `vim/_core/util.lua` is ok for now.

   end
 end
 
+function vim._validate_vimruntime()

comment_data.body: VIMRUNTIME [is special](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ce5c7111f4050f168ddf4806287b4c384264b0fa/src/nvim/os/env.c#L969) so we should probably go through `vim.fn.getenv()` here. Unless `os.getenv()` already does that?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1302,6 +1302,15 @@ function vim.deprecate(name, alternative, version, plugin, backtrace)
   end
 end
 
+function vim._validate_vimruntime()
+  local rt = os.getenv('VIMRUNTIME')

comment_regular_data.body: I wouldn't expect that checking `os_isdir` is necessary. Instead, just try to source a harmless, common file that we know is in the runtime, and handle the error. If it fails in any way, show an error explaining that VIMRUNTIME is invalid.

Now that we have `vim/_core/` , is there any reason not to implement this in Lua? I see [previous discussion](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27537#discussion_r1494955969) about about `_init_packages.lua` , but I don't think that was intended to suggest it must live in C? cc @bfredl 

 could live in `vim/_core/editor.lua` or a new file like `vim/_core/startup.lua` ?
My comment was really about what it was used _for_ (by when it was triggered) , not the implementation language. Lua has been an implantation language of core since forever.
